terms.definition: A centralized repository of information, documentation, and resources that provides answers to common questions and solutions to problems
A knowledge repository specifically designed and built to meet the unique requirements of a particular organization rather than using off-the-shelf solutions
A set of rules that allows different software applications to communicate with each other
A software distribution model where applications are hosted by a service provider and made available to customers over the internet
A company that remotely manages a customer's IT infrastructure and end-user systems
Software that enables users to create, manage, and modify content on a website without specialized technical knowledge
The process of organizing, storing, tracking, and accessing various documents within an organization
The practice of creating documentation that communicates complex technical information in a clear, accessible way for specific audiences
A collaborative knowledge platform within an organization that allows employees to create, edit, and organize content
A lightweight markup language with plain text formatting syntax designed to be converted to HTML and other formats
An architectural style for designing networked applications that uses HTTP requests to access and manipulate data
A distributed version control system for tracking changes in source code during software development
The capability of a system to handle a growing amount of work by adding resources to the system
The process of creating, sharing, using, and managing information and knowledge within an organization
The overall experience of a person using a product, especially in terms of how easy or pleasing it is to use
